column10: and antler-like branches with broad blades. This alga is second in size only to the giant kelp macrocystis
column11: and can be found in depths up to 50 m (150 ft). The stipe is rather small in relation to the large branches and blades
column12: and can break in strong storm surge. When the stipe is broken
column13: the remaining portion of the kelp will be found drifting in ocean currents
column14: and eventually washed up on beaches.|Santa Cruz Island to mid-Baja California

column17: elk kelp is somewhat unique to the Channel Islands region.|CINMS website

column7: Species menziesii|This large brown alga can be brown to olive green and has a long
column8: strap-like stipe 2 cm (1 in) wide with numerous flat
column9: feathery lateral blades and gas-filled floats. It can be  1-5 m (3.3-16.4 ft) long.|Alaska to Baja California. |Common in moderately exposed areas in low intertidal to subtidal zones.|Sunlight and dissolved nutrients via photosynthesis.|"Feather boa kelp gets its scientific name from the Latin word egregius
column10: meaning ""remarkable"". This alga has a very strong holdfast which helps it remain attached in surging waves."|CINMS website

column7: Species pyrifera|This alga is golden brown. Its stipes grow to 40 m (130 ft) with blades to 80 cm (31.5 in). Drift giant kelp and holdfasts are commonly found washed up along the shoreline and in tide pools.|West coast of North and South America in temperate waters. |Subtidal
column8: forms kelp forests on rocky reefs.|Sunlight and dissolved nutrients via photosynthesis.|Giant kelp is harvested for use in hundreds of important products
column9: including toothpaste and ice cream. Kelp forests have been compared to rain forests in terms of their importance as habitat and diversity of species.|CINMS website
